articles.title: Floods kill 238, displace 135,764 in 27 states
articles.author: Lara Adejoro
articles.summary: 238 people have died and 400,714 people have been affected by floods in 27 states and 117 local government areas as of October 10, 2025. Adamawa, Lagos, Akwa Ibom, Taraba, Imo, Imochina, Kaduna, and Rivers are the most affected states. Children account for the highest number of people affected, followed by women (125,307) and men (77,423).

articles.title: Couple takes drastic step to save home from looming threat: 'We had no choice'
articles.author: Geri Mileva
articles.summary: Scott Twentyman and Cindy Doughty had to move their beach house from Hatteras Island, North Carolina, because the shoreline is receding at an alarming rate. They spent $200,000 to move the entire structure to an adjacent lot 100 feet inland. Other coastal communities in North Carolina are facing similar threats due to climate change.

articles.title: Should we get rid of air miles for climate change?
articles.author: BBC News
articles.summary: Frequent flier schemes would seem to encourage flying and thus greenhouse gas emissions. However, the relationship is less clear-cut than it appears, according to researcher Ashley Nunes.    .      for more information visit: http://www.sciencemag.org/news/environmental-researcher/greenhouse-gas-emissions/frequent-flier-schemes/

articles.title: Column: Virginia must act to save endangered coastal wetlands
articles.author: Skip Stiles
articles.summary: Wetlands Watch estimated that Virginia would lose 50-80% of its tidal marshes by 2100 due to sea-level rise. Virginia has just established a statewide task force to find ways to protect Virginia's wetlands and plan for their health and survival. The task force will map out a path for marsh protection and make it part of Virginia's broader resilience strategies.

articles.title: 'Govt to distribute 400k vegetable seed packs'
articles.author: APP
articles.summary: Floods caused by high temperatures devastated Pakistan in August and September. Chilli farmers are struggling in a country heavily dependent on agriculture, where officials estimate $40 billion of flood damages. "When I was a child, the heat was never so intense. We used to have a plentiful crop, now it has become so hot and the rains are scarce that our yields have dwindled," farmer Leman Raj, 40, said.

articles.title: Australia's climate assessment fails on sea-level rise risks and vulnerable communities
articles.summary: Australia has just released its first-ever National Climate Risk Assessment. The assessment aims to guide adaptation responses to protect people and property in a heating climate. Some big numbers drew predictable media attention, but what happens if the reality is worse than the projections of future risks?

articles.title: Saturday, Oct. 11 update: Latest on Remnants of Jerry from the National Hurricane Center
articles.author: SUN HERALD BOT
articles.summary: Remnants of Jerry are in the Atlantic Ocean, 330 miles south-southeast of Bermuda with maximum sustained winds of 45 mph. Surf swells are affecting the Leeward Islands, Virgin Islands, Puerto Rico, Dominican Republic, Turks and Caicos Islands, and the Bahamas.

articles.title: Scientists warn that 100 MILLION buildings may be submerged due to rising sea levels – is your home vulnerable?
articles.author: Internewscast
articles.summary: Rising sea levels could plunge more than 100 million buildings underwater by 2100, according to scientists from McGill University in Montreal. If emissions are not reduced soon, sea levels will soar over 16 feet in the next century, endangering up to one-sixth of all structures in the global south. Even if the world makes good on its commitments under the Paris Agreement to reach net-zero by 2050, studies predict sea level rises will still rise by three feet by 2100.

articles.title: NASA reveals the Earth is getting darker and it could have a major impact on humanity
articles.author: Brenna Cooper
articles.summary: NASA has been monitoring Earth's radiation budget for the past 24 years. The Earth is getting darker and there is a gap between the amount of light reflected from the Northern and Southern Hemispheres. Rising temperatures are melting the Arctic's once-reflective ice caps. Melting ice caps and a decrease in pollution are thought to have contributed to this.

articles.title: Climate change and trees
articles.summary: Ian Laidlaw of Davey Tree Expert Company talks about how climate change is affecting trees in northern Ontario and across the country. He advises concerned homeowners to call a certified arborist for help if they have questions about their trees' health and safety.

articles.title: Amazon fires hit record levels, surpassing deforestation as top source of carbon emissions
articles.author: Anadolu Agency
articles.summary: The Amazon rainforest has recorded its most devastating fire season in more than two decades. Fire-related damage is now the top driver of carbon emissions in the region, according to a study by the European Commission. Urgent coordinated efforts are needed to mitigate these drivers and to prevent irreversible ecosystem damage.

articles.title: Seals, birds under threat in new 'red list' of endangered species
articles.author: The Times
articles.summary: Arctic seals and birds are under increasing threat, mainly due to climate change and human activity, according to IUCN's updated list of endangered species. Habitat loss driven by logging and climate change is the main cause of the decline of Arctic seal and bird populations.

articles.title: OP-ED: Somalia at a Crossroads: Building a Durable Solution Beyond Humanitarian Response
articles.summary: After decades of conflict, prolonged insecurity, and recurrent climate shocks, Somalia stands at a defining juncture. Somalia completed the Heavily Indebted Poor Countries (HIPC) debt relief process in December 2023. Somalia remains under Extended Credit Facility (ECF) program with the IMF. Somalia's long-term viability will depend on political stability, institutional discipline, and workable federal cooperation. Al-Shabaab continues to pose an existential threat to Somalia's national stability. Federal security institutions have been hollowed by politicisation, corruption, and dysfunction.

articles.title: Climate change one of the biggest challenges to tea industry: experts
articles.author: Shiv Sahay Singh
articles.summary: Floods and landslides ravaged north Bengal last week. Nearly 30 of the 276 tea gardens of the region have been affected by the deluge. The industry is yet to come up with a figure of how much damage has been incurred. Ravi Kota, Chief Secretary of Assam, said that climate change is the biggest long-term risk to the industry.

articles.title: How Hurricanes Influence Wildlife Migration Patterns
articles.author: SCIENMAG
articles.summary: In a world shaped by climate change, understanding how populations respond to natural disasters has never been more critical. A study highlights the migratory behavior of populations in the United States following hurricanes and tropical storms from 1992 to 2017. It suggests that people prefer to stay in familiar surroundings even in the face of danger. The study's conclusions could inform disaster preparedness strategies.

articles.title: Amazon fires hit record levels, surpassing deforestation as top source of carbon emissions
articles.author: Esra Tekin
articles.summary: The Amazon has recorded its most devastating fire season in more than two decades. Fires burned 3.3 million hectares of rainforest in 2024, unleashing record carbon emissions and accelerating ecosystem degradation. The 2024 fire season released about 791 million tons of carbon dioxide into the atmosphere.

articles.title: Seals, birds under threat in new 'red list' of endangered species
articles.author: AFP
articles.summary: IUCN has updated its endangered species list. The list now includes 172,620 species of which 48,646 are threatened with extinction. The status of the hooded seal has been changed from vulnerable to endangered. The bearded and harp seals are now classified as near threatened. Global warming is destroying the natural habitat of animals including seals.

articles.title: The tale of two Los Cabos: Paradise for foreigners, lack of services for locals
articles.author: Ian Hayden Parker
articles.summary: Hurricane Priscilla Baja intensifies and prompts the state to suspend classes in Los Cabos and Baja California Sur and La Paz because of the storm. The state does not have any schools in Baja, La Paza and Los Cabo.

articles.title: Torrential rains in Spain caused flooding and evacuations
articles.author: Eli Stoanova
articles.summary: Torrential rains have caused flooding and forced the evacuation of dozens of people in the southeastern Spanish autonomous region of Murcia. The head of the local government, Fernando López Miras, called on residents of Campo de Cartagena and Mazarrón districts to 'avoid unnecessary travel and be careful'. The mayor of Los Alcázares district advised people living in lower areas to settle on the first floors of their homes and stock up on essential products.

articles.title: Los Cabos storm shelters open as Raymond nears land
articles.author: Ian Hayden Parker
articles.summary: Hurricane Priscilla Baja intensifies and prompts the state to suspend classes in Los Cabos and Baja California Sur and La Paz because of the storm. The state does not have any schools in Baja, La Paza and Los Cabo.

articles.title: Coastal flood advisory issued for Alexandria and Arlington; NWS warns of tidal flooding
articles.author: Hindustan Times
articles.summary: After hurricane and heavy rain warnings in the US, the National Weather Service has issued a coastal flood advisory for the Alexandria shoreline and Arlington County. It will last from midnight Saturday until 4 AM (local time) on Monday, October 13. It warns of flooding in low-lying areas.

articles.title: RELIGION: The importance of Awe in everyday life
articles.author: Rev. Dr. Arlyn Macdonald
articles.summary: Flocks of Canada geese gathered in the pasture behind home this morning to welcome the new day. As soon as they landed, each one of them turned east towards the rising sun to honor their Creator. A few days later, the geese returned to the pasture in the late afternoon to stand in solemn silence to honor the setting sun.

articles.title: Summers in Japan longer by 3 weeks over 42 years, researchers say
articles.summary: Japanese summers have lengthened by about three weeks over the 42 years from 1982 to 2023. The rise in sea surface temperatures due to global warming is the main factor. The trend towards longer summers and longer winters will intensify if warming continues, according to Mie University research group.

articles.title: World Migratory Bird Day celebrated at Puthalam saltpans
articles.author: The Hindu Bureau
articles.summary: Tamil Nadu Forest Department, in association with Migratory bird monitoring trust, on Saturday observed World migratory bird day at saltpans in Puthalam near Manakudy in Kanniyakumari district. The event saw participation from school and college students who took part in bird watching and other interactive sessions.

articles.title: Bird flu cases are spiking earlier than experts expected — and that could cause egg ...
articles.author: The Independent
articles.summary: Millions of birds are laying eggs, sending egg prices soaring. Experts warn there's no end in sight.      Â   .   e.g. egg prices are going up.  e-gives are going down.

articles.title: Global Warning: Our future in a warmer world
articles.summary: Global Warning is a three-part series on the realities of climate change and innovative solutions to safeguard our future in a warmer world. It's based on the book Global Warning: Our Future in a Warming World by Michael Bociurkiw and is published by Simon & Schuster.

articles.title: Union County, NC Residents Encouraged to Review Preliminary FEMA Flood Maps Before December 17 Deadline
articles.author: Liam Patterson
articles.summary: Federal Emergency Management Agency is updating Union County's flood maps to refine flood risk zones. The preliminary maps are now available for public review. Residents are encouraged to submit comments or appeals before the December 17 deadline. The finalized maps will shape insurance rates, building codes, and future development in flood-prone areas.

articles.title: Global Warning: Our future in a warmer world
articles.summary: A three-part series on the realities of climate change, but with innovative solutions to safeguard our future. Irish journalist Philip Boucher-Hayes visits climate hotspots, from Greenland's melting glaciers to sub-Saharan Africa's weather extremes. He meets experts and witnesses who explain the interconnectivity of the world's fragile ecology.

articles.title: Global Warning: Our future in a warmer world
articles.summary: Global Warning is a three-part series on the realities of climate change and innovative solutions to safeguard our future in a warmer world. It's based on the book Global Warning: Our Future in a Warming World by Michael Bociurkiw and is published by Simon & Schuster.

articles.title: Global Warning: Our future in a warmer world
articles.author: News Feed Editor
articles.summary: A three-part series on the realities of climate change, but with innovative solutions to safeguard our future. Irish journalist Philip Boucher-Hayes visits climate hotspots, from Greenland's melting glaciers to sub-Saharan Africa's weather extremes. He meets experts who explain the interconnectivity of the world's fragile ecology.

articles.title: Inside the scramble to save lives as heat menaces two Southwestern counties
articles.author: News Feed Editor
articles.summary: by | | Climate Change is a website dedicated to the study of climate change. For more information, visit: http://www.climatalkin.org/news/environment/environmental-change/chimatockexchange.html.

articles.title: Millions of Birds Are Migrating — Here's How To Help Keep Them Safe
articles.author: Floyd County Chronicle
articles.summary: Millions of birds are migrating south for the winter. Experts say people can help them have a safe trip, as they face dangerous obstacles on their journey.    for the next HealthDay News broadcast on Saturday, October 11, 2025, at 10 a.m. ET.

articles.title: La Niña conditions return to United States, but weaker this time; to linger through Feb 2026
articles.author: Livemint
articles.summary: La Niña conditions have returned in the United States, but they are expected to remain weak. La Niña is a climate pattern that cools surface temperatures in the central and eastern equatorial Pacific Ocean. It is a major factor influencing the US weather from late fall through early spring.

articles.title: Survival of Europe's bees and butterflies at risk, conservationists warn
articles.author: Straits Times
articles.summary: Habitat loss and climate change are related to climate change, as are habitat loss and habitat loss.    .   "Climate change is a human-caused phenomenon.  "Habitat loss" and "climate change" are related.

articles.title: World Migratory Bird Day: Aerial visitors over lands and waters
articles.author: CGTN
articles.summary: World Migratory Bird Day is celebrated on the second Saturday of May and October. This year's theme is "Shared spaces: Creating bird-friendly cities and communities". This photo collection follows migratory birds as they glide over mountains, farmlands, coasts and wetlands.

articles.title: Is the Great Blackout Coming? Nasa Releases Alarming Analysis
articles.summary: According to NASA satellite data, the Earth is getting darker and the Northern Hemisphere is absorbing more sunlight than the Southern Hemisphere. This could accelerate climate change, according to the scientists.   Â. Â   y.  y   .

articles.title: Pollution-driven Decline In Sunshine Hours Threatens India's Solar Output
articles.author: BW Online Bureau
articles.summary: Sunshine hours in India have declined steadily over the past three decades. The north Indian plains recorded the steepest decline, while the west coast saw a reduction of 8.6 hours per year. The east coast, the Deccan plateau, and central inland regions also registered declines of 4.9, 3.1, and 4.7 hours annually. Only the northeast region showed a marginal seasonal level. Declines were most pronounced during the monsoon months.

articles.title: Northeast Monsoon Arrives in Tamil Nadu with Heavy Rain Forecast
articles.author: Naveen
articles.summary: Nilgiris, Coimbatore, Tiruppur, Dindigul, Theni, Madurai, Sivaganga, Dharmapuri, Salem, Tiruvannamalai, and Tirupattur districts are likely to experience heavy to very heavy rainfall, accompanied by thunder and lightning. The weather office has issued a warning for fishermen, advising them not to venture into the sea in the southern coastal regions, Gulf of Mannar, and adjoining Comorin Sea. In Chennai, partly cloudy skies are expected, with moderate rainfall or thunderstorms likely in a few areas during the evening and night hours.

articles.title: St Mary's celebrates farmers in harvest festival
articles.author: News Staff
articles.summary: Parishioners of St Mary's Church in Warwick celebrated a traditional harvest service in the wake of hurricanes Humberto and Imelda last Sunday. Carlos Amaral, chairman of the Bermuda Farmers' Association, was the guest speaker at the special service to recognise the importance of local farmers.

articles.title: Young people's climate change artwork exhibit opens in Devon
articles.author: News Feed Editor
articles.summary: Young people's climate change artwork exhibit opens in Devon BBC BBC.    .   Read More at Article Source.  Read more at article source. Share this article with a link to the article you want people to read. Back to the page you came from

articles.title: Millions of Birds Are Migrating — Here's How To Help Keep Them Safe
articles.author: Health Day
articles.summary: This week saw the biggest migration event ever recorded by the BirdCast, a bird study project at Cornell University in Ithaca, New York. More than 36 million birds have already migrated this fall. People can help birds have a safe trip by keeping cats indoors, turning off unnecessary outdoor lighting at night and using window mitigation.

articles.title: Millions of Birds Are Migrating Across Florida. Here's How You Can Help Them.
articles.summary: BirdCast tracked the largest migration ever, recording 1.25 billion migrating birds across North America this fall. Migratory birds face hazards like collisions, light pollution, habitat loss, predators and storms. Residents and homeowners should act now to protect migratory birds.

articles.title: Millions of Birds Are Migrating — Here's How To Help Keep Them Safe
articles.summary: This week saw the biggest migration event ever recorded by the BirdCast, a bird study project at Cornell University in Ithaca, New York — 1.25 billion birds. More than 36 million birds have already migrated this fall, according to trackers at Virginia Tech University.

articles.title: Millions of Birds Are Migrating — Here's How To Help Keep Them Safe
articles.summary: Millions of birds are migrating south for the winter. Experts say people can help them have a safe trip, as they face dangerous obstacles on their journey.    for the next HealthDay News broadcast on Saturday, October 11, 2025, at 10 a.m. ET.

articles.title: Millions of Birds Are Migrating — Here's How To Help Keep Them Safe
articles.summary: A flock of migrating birds in the sky above the sea was photographed by healthday.com.    It was part of the BLOX Digital Content Exchange and is available on Healthday's digital content exchange platform BLOX digitalcontent.com, part of BLOX Media Exchange.

articles.title: Millions of Birds Are Migrating — Here's How To Help Keep Them Safe
articles.summary: A flock of migrating birds in the sky above the sea was photographed by healthday.com, part of the BLOX Digital Content Exchange. There was an error processing the request to sign up for the list, so the link to confirm the signup was not sent.

articles.title: ‘Solar maximum': More storms from the sun could bring more Northern Lights, potential disruptions
articles.author: Wikimedia Commons
articles.summary: The sun is at the height of a cycle which sees its north and south poles flip approximately every 11 years. More of the world, including parts of the continental U.S., could see increased instances of Aurora Borealis lights over the next several months.

articles.title: ‘Solar maximum': More storms from the sun could bring more Northern Lights, potential power grid, technology disruptions
articles.author: Frank Olsen
articles.summary: The sun is at the height of a cycle which sees its north and south poles flip approximately every 11 years. More of the world, including parts of the continental U.S., could see increased instances of Aurora Borealis lights over the next several months.

articles.title: Torrential rains in Mexico leave nearly 30 dead
articles.author: Web Desk
articles.summary: Torrential rains have caused disastrous floods and landslides in Mexico. At least 28 people were killed and extensive destruction was caused. The Hidalgo state is one of the most severely affected areas. In the Gulf coast state of Veracruz, two people have been killed, including a cop, and some 5,000 homes have been destroyed. The Mexican Navy has rescued close to 900 citizens in Queretaro.

articles.title: Climate crisis threatens nearly half of natural World Heritage sites, report finds
articles.author: Rachel Kelly
articles.summary: Nearly half of natural World Heritage sites are under severe threat from climate change, according to the IUCN's World Heritage Outlook 4 report. The report paints the most comprehensive picture yet of the health of the world's 271 natural World heritage sites, from tropical forests to coral reefs. There is a decade-long decline in the conservation outlook of the World Heritage Sites, with 57% having a positive future.

articles.title: Honolulu seeks new Chief Resilience Officer
articles.author: Ian Bauer
articles.summary: Honolulu's next chief resilience officer will succeed Ben Sullivan, who left the city earlier this month to pursue other career opportunities. Mayor Rick Blangiardi announced Friday that the City and County of Honolulu is currently accepting applications from highly-qualified individuals for the position. The position is responsible for advancing the city's mission to build more resilient communities across Oahu.

articles.title: Okie-Tex starry night
articles.author: Astronomy
articles.summary: Stars swirl around Polaris to the north and arc across the sky to the south in this 360 degree view from Phoenix, Arizona. Greg Meyer took this photo from Phoenix.       .   for Greg Meyer from Phoenix,. Arizona.  For Greg Meyer,

articles.title: Hungry ghosts taught me about the urgency of living in a way that respects the past
articles.author: Alice Mah
articles.summary: The climate crisis is destroying lands, homes and species, but also ruining important cultural sites and sacred spaces around the world. UNESCO reports on the significant impact of climate change on world heritage. One day the air is clean, the moss-covered trees damp, the forest paths well-trodden, the next day the trees are alight and the sky fills with thick, dark smoke.

articles.title: If there's one thing that all Canadians can feel grateful for on Thanksgiving, it's this
articles.author: Janice Kennedy
articles.summary: Readers' Choice Voting is now open. Click here to vote for your favourites. Janice Kennedy is a retired journalist who lives in Ottawa. She writes opinion articles based on the author's interpretations and judgments of facts, data and events. The article is free for subscribers.

articles.title: With chilly winter forecast, help is available for heating bills
articles.author: John Halley Athens Messenger
articles.summary: HAPCAP is helping Athens County residents stay warm by helping them with their heating bills as winter is coming closer.       - HAPCAP's website is: http://www.hapcap.org/help-people-with-heating-bills.

articles.title: The gorgeous country that's 33C in October offering Brits £56,000 salaries to move there
articles.author: Grace Piercy
articles.summary: Nurses from the UK will have job applications in Australia fast-tracked. Australia is a popular choice for Brits looking to move away from home thanks to its warm weather and laid-back reputation. There are currently 1.2 million British expats living in Australia, with around 50,000 people moving there on a working holiday visa last year.

articles.title: Quiz: How Much Do You Know About Migratory Birds?
articles.author: Mirage News
articles.summary: World Migratory Bird Day 2025 is being held globally on 11 October under the theme "Shared Spaces: Creating Bird-Friendly Cities and Communities". Habitat loss, pollution, climate change, and other human pressures are causing alarming declines of migratory birds.

articles.title: Big change comes to travel to Europe
articles.summary: Big changes are imminent for Australians travelling to Europe. It will spell the end of stamps in your passport.       .   for travellers to Europe and it will be easier for them to apply for a new passport. For more information, visit www.australianpassage.com.

articles.title: Big changes are imminent for Australians travelling to Europe, and it'll spell the end of stamps in your passport.
articles.summary: Big changes are imminent for Australians travelling to Europe. It will spell the end of stamps in your passport.       .   for travellers to Europe and it will be easier for them to apply for a new passport. For more information, visit www.australianpassage.com.

articles.title: Powerful 7.8 magnitude earthquake strikes the Drake Passage, triggering tsunami alert
articles.author: newsroom
articles.summary: A powerful earthquake measuring 7.8 on the Richter scale occurred in the early hours of Saturday in the area of the Drake Passage, between Cape Horn in South America and the South Shetland Islands of Antarctica. There are no reports of damage or casualties. The Pacific Tsunami Warning Centre issued a warning for a potential tsunami.

articles.title: Dorset residents urged to take part in 2026 Birdwatch
articles.author: Deb Gayen
articles.summary: The RSPB's Big Garden Birdwatch, which began in 1979, is returning this January. The annual event asks people to spend one hour counting the birds they see in their garden, park, or from their balcony. The survey provides a snapshot of how garden birds are faring across the UK and is considered a significant way to take action for birds and nature. In 2025, nearly 8,900 people in Dorset joined the count, with house sparrows, blue tits, and wood pigeons being the most commonly sighted birds. In 2026, residents are asked to count the birds that land in their chosen space for one hour over the weekend of January 23 to January 25

articles.title: The climate's emergency brake
articles.author: Daphne Wysham
articles.summary: Methane levels in the atmosphere are rising at a record pace despite pledges by 159 countries to cut methane emissions 30 percent by 2030. Daphne Wysham is CEO of Methane Action and a moderator of a Climate Week event on meeting the methane emergency.

articles.title: La Niña is back. It could mean another dangerously dry winter for Southern California
articles.author: Grace Toohey
articles.summary: After months of slight temperature shifts in the Pacific Ocean, La Niña has officially returned. It's the climate pattern that typically drives drought in Southern California. The National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration announced Thursday that La Niñas have arrived. It could be a foreboding sign for California.

articles.title: La Niña is here, but what does that mean for Middle Georgia?
articles.author: Noah Hauck
articles.summary: The Climate Prediction Center announced that a La Niña is now present. It's one of three different climate patterns for the Pacific Ocean categorized as an ENSO (El Niño/Southern Oscillation). La Niñas affect the Eastern Pacific Ocean and the Northern Pacific Ocean. They are predicted to last for the remainder of 2025 and the first three months of 2026.

articles.title: The net zero myth
articles.author: Howard Thomas Brady
articles.summary: There is no credible link between the rise in greenhouse gases and the global warming since the middle of the 19th Century. There were at least 70 years of temperature pauses in the past 150 years while carbon dioxide levels increased without any global warming. There are more important factors in the climate system that far outweigh any climate effects due to changes in greenhouse gas levels. Carbon dioxide levels above 430 parts per million pose no danger to human life.

articles.title: Nigeria Not Yet Prepared To Confront Climate Change Crisis –ED, GIFSEP
articles.author: Alex Egbochie
articles.summary: Climate change is a long-term shift in weather patterns caused by human activities. It's affecting all parts of Nigeria, especially in the North, where temperatures are rising, the land is drying up, and desertification is swallowing farmlands. Nigeria has launched a National Climate Change Policy and established the National Council on Climate Change (NCCC) to coordinate climate action. It signed the Paris Accord and pledged to achieve net-zero emissions by 2060.

articles.title: Nigeria's Dilemma Over Variations In Weather Patterns
articles.author: Alex Egbochie
articles.summary: Nigeria is on the forefront of an escalating climate crisis due to climate change. In the last 10 years alone, there has been an unprecedented level of changes in the amount of flood system in Nigeria. The average of daily weather conditions for about 30 years is called climate, but the climate is never the same from one 30-year period to another. Human development activities such as urbanisation, agriculture and livestock and industrialisation are accelerating the rate of change. Economic costs are reflected in the areas of financial losses and rising debts.

articles.title: Project extends mangrove walk
articles.author: Allison Vaughn
articles.summary: The Roger Downing Mangrove Boardwalk is being extended by 990 feet. The Sir Richard Branson-backed foundation is funding the project through a $100,000 donation. The extension is more than half finished, with 550 feet of new boardwalk already in place, but more money may be needed. Rotary Club of Tortola is working on further fundraising.

articles.title: Eco-anxiety rising
articles.author: The Newspaper
articles.summary: The link between climate change and mental health is often overlooked. Monsoon-inspired floods killed hundreds of people and displaced millions this year. Climate-induced migration, food insecurity and loss of livelihoods add to psychological distress. Farmers and labourers working in extreme weather conditions face economic hardship and eco-anxiety. Public awareness campaigns, counselling services, and community support programmes must be integrated into climate adaptation strategies.

articles.title: Climate-resilience is our only option
articles.author: The Newspaper
articles.summary: Pakistan's fight against climate change requires urgent and bold steps. The recent catastrophic floods in Punjab, affecting over two million people, highlighted how deeply and directly national security and social stability are linked to climate vulnerabilities. Pakistan can safeguard its future and uphold its commitment to sustainable development by making climate security a central point.

articles.title: Baltimore harbor makes strides in latest report card, but lingering issues remain
articles.author: Mathew Schumer
articles.summary: La Nina is back, but it's weak and may be brief. Will it still amp up the Atlantic hurricane season? It's too early to tell, but the hurricane season is still going to be active. It's not clear if La Nina will be a hurricane force.

articles.title: Our planet is literally getting darker ...
articles.author: Source: Xinhua
articles.summary: Earth has reflected less sunlight over the past two decades due to an unbalanced "radiation budget" according to NASA. This planetary dimming is a red flag of global warming and a sign of big shifts ahead, according to Xinhua Global Service.

articles.title: Changing leaf color in the fall
articles.author: Annette Meyer Heisdorffer
articles.summary: Most tree and shrub leaves are green in the summer because of large amounts of chlorophyll within each leaf. Chlorophyll combines with sunlight to produce the needed food for tree growth. Other colors are present in leaves, but the large amount of green chlorophylla masks these colors.

articles.title: In one of Australia's fastest-shrinking regions, towns are fighting to remain
articles.author: system
articles.summary: In Yarriambiack Shire, 350 km from Melbourne, virtually all of the towns are shrinking, as shown in the map.    in the rural north-west of Victoria's rural north west, there are fewer people living in the towns.

articles.title: La Niña is back. It could mean another dangerously dry winter for Southern California
articles.author: The Brunswick News
articles.summary: After months of slight temperature shifts in the Pacific Ocean, La Niña has stopped. The change is due to the La Niñas.   Â   in the ocean's surface temperature. Â "La Niña is no longer a tropical cyclone.

articles.title: Photos: Flight sights at Hawk Ridge in Duluth
articles.author: Duluth News Tribune
articles.summary: The Everyone Can Bird: Fall Migration event took place at Hawk Ridge Bird Observatory at 3980 E. Skyline Parkway on Saturday. Saturday also happened to be World Migratory Bird Day. October is peak migration season for some of the migratory birds in North America.

articles.title: Global Warning: Our future in a warmer world
articles.author: Al Jazeera
articles.summary: This decisive decade demands unprecedented action to address humanity's greatest challenge, climate change. With global access, this three-part series examines the real consequences of climate change for our civilisation, through the rest of the century. It's called "The End of History".
